Notes
This module is due to commence in January 2022

Change to assessment weighting as part of light touch approval-. Cycle 2 assessment changed from 2000-2500 to 2000 words max

Marketing synopsis and overview also updated

Dr Hannah Betts from LSTM teaches on this module. Currently not appearing in the Global Address List so cannot be added to staff list.

Overview

Overview
Each lecture focuses on a different aspect of global health theory and practice. Teaching material and discussions are based on the professional experience of world-leading experts from the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, providing concrete and applicable scenarios to think through the possibilities and shortcomings of global and public health interventions. Specifically, the module will cover:

Public hesitancy to follow health guidelines (e.g., vaccination, condoms, bednet use);
Intersectional approaches to health;
Challenges in humanitarian settings;
Data use in implementation;
Vector-borne diseases’ transmission and treatment in local contexts;
The global impact of snake bite;
Epidemiology of HIV, TB, and Malaria.

Successful students will achieve a critical understanding of the complex circumstances in which health interventions are implemented. They will be able to adopt a fluid and contextual frameworks to assess feasibility of health interventions and to think through the variables that might affect intervention outcomes.

Delivery of the module is hybrid: online, pre-recorded lectures (1h/week) will be accompanied by face-to-face presentations and tutorials (2h/week). Student progress will be assessed through two essays (one at the end of Cycle 1, which will contribute 40% to the final mark; the other at the end of Cycle 2, contributing 60% to the final mark).

Skill/Other Attribute 1: Critical Thinking
How this is developed: Use of case studies across the module; weekly tutorials with expansions and commentaries on lectures.

Skill/Other Attribute 2: Communication Skills
How this is developed: Development of essays drawing across a variety of disciplines and epistemologies.

Skill/Other Attribute 3: Ethical Awareness
How this is developed: Scenarios and cases led by researchers with years of experience in global health and primary data collection.

Skills/Other Attribute 4: International Awareness
How this is developed: Lectures and tutorials designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.
Educational Aims
To enhance students' awareness of the global distribution of disease and the associated implications and inequalities;

To enhance students' understanding of the complexity of global phenomena of heath, disease, and care, including the role of social determinants of health and the social lives of diseases;

To develop students' knowledge and deep understanding in the tropical disease biology and their ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases.

It aims to enhance awareness of the global distribution of disease and the impact of poverty induced inequalities in access to effective and affordable treatments.

Through lectures and tutorials, the module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases. Lectures and tutorials are designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.

Students' progress is assessed through two summative essays (Cycle 1 and Cycle 2) that will contribute to the final mark at 40% and 60%. The essays ask the students to critically evaluate scenarios in global health by applying the knowledge and skills acquired in the module.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Vaccines, vaccinations, and anti-vax movements. Global disease burden of the neglected tropical diseases, filariasis, onchocerciasis, schistosomiasis, snakebite, dengue. The impact of these diseases upon the rural tropical poor. Snakebite and dengue;

Topic 2: Gender-driven inequity in tropical health

Topic 3: Biomass and global respiratory diseases

Topic 4: Key funders and stakeholders

Topic 5: Challenges in Humanitarian Assistance

Topic 6: Global elimination of Filariasis

Topic 7: The global impact of snakebite

Topic 8: Disease burden of Schistosomiasis

Topic 9: Dengue in the Tropics

Topic 10: Global issue of Malaria, TB, and HIV

Module material will be delivered primarily through standard and recorded lectures, supported by materials on the VLE and other web-based resources. Regular tutorials will guide students through specialised topic areas. Students will be guided to key articles in the literature, textbooks, original papers, and review articles, be expected to use this material to supplement their independent learning and be provided with feedback on the essay writing.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled lectures in which key concepts are explained. 12 x 1 hour asynchronous lectures and 12 x 1 synchronous lectures, to be delivered together with a tutorial.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to 12 x 1 hour synchronous tutorials
Attendance Recorded: Yes
These are very much Q&A sessions, following a 1-hour face-to-face lecture.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading during the first part of the module.
Assessment 2: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading over the whole course of the module.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency and critical thinking in our students, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Through lectures and tutorials, the module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases. Lectures and tutorials are designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.

Students' progress is assessed through two summative essays (Cycle 1 and Cycle 2) that will contribute to the final mark at 40% and 60%. The essays ask the students to critically evaluate scenarios in global health by applying the knowledge and skills acquired in the module.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Vaccines, vaccinations, and anti-vax movements. Global disease burden of the neglected tropical diseases, filariasis, onchocerciasis, schistosomiasis, snakebite, dengue. The impact of these diseases upon the rural tropical poor. Snakebite and dengue;

Topic 2: Gender-driven inequity in tropical health

Topic 3: Biomass and global respiratory diseases

Topic 4: Key funders and stakeholders

Topic 5: Challenges in Humanitarian Assistance

Topic 6: Global elimination of Filariasis

Topic 7: The global impact of snakebite

Topic 8: Disease burden of Schistosomiasis

Topic 9: Dengue in the Tropics

Topic 10: Global issue of Malaria, TB, and HIV

Module material will be delivered primarily through standard and recorded lectures, supported by materials on the VLE and other web-based resources. Regular tutorials will guide students through specialised topic areas. Students will be guided to key articles in the literature, textbooks, original papers, and review articles, be expected to use this material to supplement their independent learning and be provided with feedback on the essay writing.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled lectures in which key concepts are explained. 12 x 1 hour asynchronous lectures and 12 x 1 synchronous lectures, to be delivered together with a tutorial.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to 12 x 1 hour synchronous tutorials
Attendance Recorded: Yes
These are very much Q&A sessions, following a 1-hour face-to-face lecture.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading during the first part of the module.
Assessment 2: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading over the whole course of the module.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency and critical thinking in our students, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes

Change to assessment weighting as part of light touch approval-. Cycle 2 assessment changed from 2000-2500 to 2000 words max

Marketing synopsis and overview also updated

Dr Hannah Betts from LSTM teaches on this module. Currently not appearing in the Global Address List so cannot be added to staff list.

Overview

Overview
Each lecture focuses on a different aspect of global health theory and practice. Teaching material and discussions are based on the professional experience of world-leading experts from the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, providing concrete and applicable scenarios to think through the possibilities and shortcomings of global and public health interventions. Specifically, the module will cover:

Public hesitancy to follow health guidelines (e.g., vaccination, condoms, bednet use);
Intersectional approaches to health;
Challenges in humanitarian settings;
Data use in implementation;
Vector-borne diseases’ transmission and treatment in local contexts;
The global impact of snake bite;
Epidemiology of HIV, TB, and Malaria.

Successful students will achieve a critical understanding of the complex circumstances in which health interventions are implemented. They will be able to adopt a fluid and contextual frameworks to assess feasibility of health interventions and to think through the variables that might affect intervention outcomes.

Delivery of the module is hybrid: online, pre-recorded lectures (1h/week) will be accompanied by face-to-face presentations and tutorials (2h/week). Student progress will be assessed through two essays (one at the end of Cycle 1, which will contribute 40% to the final mark; the other at the end of Cycle 2, contributing 60% to the final mark).

Skill/Other Attribute 1: Critical Thinking
How this is developed: Use of case studies across the module; weekly tutorials with expansions and commentaries on lectures.

Skill/Other Attribute 2: Communication Skills
How this is developed: Development of essays drawing across a variety of disciplines and epistemologies.

Skill/Other Attribute 3: Ethical Awareness
How this is developed: Scenarios and cases led by researchers with years of experience in global health and primary data collection.

Skills/Other Attribute 4: International Awareness
How this is developed: Lectures and tutorials designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.
Educational Aims
To enhance students' awareness of the global distribution of disease and the associated implications and inequalities;

To enhance students' understanding of the complexity of global phenomena of heath, disease, and care, including the role of social determinants of health and the social lives of diseases;

To develop students' knowledge and deep understanding in the tropical disease biology and their ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases.

It aims to enhance awareness of the global distribution of disease and the impact of poverty induced inequalities in access to effective and affordable treatments.

Through lectures and tutorials, the module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases. Lectures and tutorials are designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.

Notes
This module is due to commence in January 2022

Change to assessment weighting as part of light touch approval-. Cycle 2 assessment changed from 2000-2500 to 2000 words max

Marketing synopsis and overview also updated

Dr Hannah Betts from LSTM teaches on this module. Currently not appearing in the Global Address List so cannot be added to staff list.

Overview

Overview
Each lecture focuses on a different aspect of global health theory and practice. Teaching material and discussions are based on the professional experience of world-leading experts from the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, providing concrete and applicable scenarios to think through the possibilities and shortcomings of global and public health interventions. Specifically, the module will cover:

Public hesitancy to follow health guidelines (e.g., vaccination, condoms, bednet use);
Intersectional approaches to health;
Challenges in humanitarian settings;
Data use in implementation;
Vector-borne diseases’ transmission and treatment in local contexts;
The global impact of snake bite;
Epidemiology of HIV, TB, and Malaria.

Successful students will achieve a critical understanding of the complex circumstances in which health interventions are implemented. They will be able to adopt a fluid and contextual frameworks to assess feasibility of health interventions and to think through the variables that might affect intervention outcomes.

Delivery of the module is hybrid: online, pre-recorded lectures (1h/week) will be accompanied by face-to-face presentations and tutorials (2h/week). Student progress will be assessed through two essays (one at the end of Cycle 1, which will contribute 40% to the final mark; the other at the end of Cycle 2, contributing 60% to the final mark).

Skill/Other Attribute 1: Critical Thinking
How this is developed: Use of case studies across the module; weekly tutorials with expansions and commentaries on lectures.

Skill/Other Attribute 2: Communication Skills
How this is developed: Development of essays drawing across a variety of disciplines and epistemologies.

Skill/Other Attribute 3: Ethical Awareness
How this is developed: Scenarios and cases led by researchers with years of experience in global health and primary data collection.

Skills/Other Attribute 4: International Awareness
How this is developed: Lectures and tutorials designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.
Educational Aims
To enhance students' awareness of the global distribution of disease and the associated implications and inequalities;

To enhance students' understanding of the complexity of global phenomena of heath, disease, and care, including the role of social determinants of health and the social lives of diseases;

To develop students' knowledge and deep understanding in the tropical disease biology and their ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge to solve complex problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases.

It aims to enhance awareness of the global distribution of disease and the impact of poverty induced inequalities in access to effective and affordable treatments.

Through lectures and tutorials, the module gives students a broad understanding of the public health significance of tropical infectious and non-infectious diseases. Lectures and tutorials are designed and led by international and multidisciplinary cohort of global health professionals.

Students' progress is assessed through two summative essays (Cycle 1 and Cycle 2) that will contribute to the final mark at 40% and 60%. The essays ask the students to critically evaluate scenarios in global health by applying the knowledge and skills acquired in the module.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Vaccines, vaccinations, and anti-vax movements. Global disease burden of the neglected tropical diseases, filariasis, onchocerciasis, schistosomiasis, snakebite, dengue. The impact of these diseases upon the rural tropical poor. Snakebite and dengue;

Topic 2: Gender-driven inequity in tropical health

Topic 3: Biomass and global respiratory diseases

Topic 4: Key funders and stakeholders

Topic 5: Challenges in Humanitarian Assistance

Topic 6: Global elimination of Filariasis

Topic 7: The global impact of snakebite

Topic 8: Disease burden of Schistosomiasis

Topic 9: Dengue in the Tropics

Topic 10: Global issue of Malaria, TB, and HIV

Module material will be delivered primarily through standard and recorded lectures, supported by materials on the VLE and other web-based resources. Regular tutorials will guide students through specialised topic areas. Students will be guided to key articles in the literature, textbooks, original papers, and review articles, be expected to use this material to supplement their independent learning and be provided with feedback on the essay writing.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled lectures in which key concepts are explained. 12 x 1 hour asynchronous lectures and 12 x 1 synchronous lectures, to be delivered together with a tutorial.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to 12 x 1 hour synchronous tutorials
Attendance Recorded: Yes
These are very much Q&A sessions, following a 1-hour face-to-face lecture.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading during the first part of the module.
Assessment 2: The open book written coursework will consist of a single question designed to test critical thinking of the knowledge gained from taught material and from extra reading over the whole course of the module.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency and critical thinking in our students, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
